title: Mjøndalen
text:
Mjøndalen is a <a href="built%20up%20area">built up area</a> in <a href="Drammen">Drammen</a> municipality in <a href="Viken%20%28county%29">Viken county</a> (formerly <a href="Buskerud%20County%20Municipality">Buskerud county</a>), <a href="Norway">Norway</a>. It is situated south of the <a href="Drammenselva">Drammenselva</a> River opposite of <a href="Krokstadelva">Krokstadelva</a>.
History.
Mjøndalen has traditionally been a railway site most known as an industrial sawmill location. Historically Mjøndalen was known for its industry; including paper & pulp production and a substantial <a href="cellulose">cellulose</a> industry. The production of wood products and furniture are also traditional commercial activities. All the paper mills closed in the late 1960s and early 1970s.
Sports and media.
Mjøndalen has a friendly sports rivalry with the neighbouring communities of <a href="Solbergelva">Solbergelva</a> and <a href="Krokstadelva">Krokstadelva</a>. The rivalry is mostly in sports such as <a href="association%20football">football</a> and <a href="bandy">bandy</a> and <a href="cross-country%20skiing%20%28sport%29">cross-country skiing</a>. In football, <a href="Mj%C3%B8ndalen%20IF%20Fotball">Mjøndalen IF Fotball</a> plays in <a href="Eliteserien">Eliteserien</a>, the top tier in the Norwegian league system. In bandy, <a href="Mj%C3%B8ndalen%20IF">Mjøndalen IF</a> have become Norwegian champions several times. The newspaper "<a href="Eikerbladet">Eikerbladet</a>" is published in Mjøndalen.
Mjøndalen Church.
Mjøndalen Church ("Mjøndalen Kirke") was opened in 1983. It was built after drawings by architect Elisabeth Breen Fidjestøl. The building was constructed of brick and wood and has 380 seats. The building consists of the church sanctuary and adjacent church hall, offices, chapel and youth department and group rooms. It is part of the <a href="Church%20of%20Norway">Church of Norway</a> and belongs to Eiker Prosti in the <a href="Diocese%20of%20Tunsberg">Diocese of Tunsberg</a>.
Portåsen.
Portåsen is a museum honouring the life and writing of <a href="Herman%20Wildenvey">Herman Wildenvey</a>, a prominent Norwegian poet. Herman Wildenvey lived the first three years of his life in Mjøndalen. At three years of age, he was moved to the Portåsen farm on the edge of the forest above the village.
Today Portåsen, Wildenveys rike is a cultural centre, meeting place and venue for local, regional and national artists. The site includes a newly renovated farmhouse and farm buildings. Stiftelsen Portåsen is the organization which works on the development of Portåsen and which operates in affiliation with Buskerud Museum ("Buskerudmuseet"), a foundation for the preservation of cultural heritage within Buskerud.
